Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Scalable phylogenomics at the species level: a novel target-gene approach to tracing the global diversification of prorhynchid flatworms (Platyhelminthes)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The prorhynchid flatworms are a diverse and abundant group of predatory microscopic invertebrates living in humid soils and freshwaters on all regions of the globe. However, as is the case with most animals showing small body size, simple anatomy, and cryptic habitats, their biodiversity has gone almost entirely unstudied by modern biologists; unnamed species may outnumber the 29 species known to science by the hundreds, and their evolutionary relationships are essentially unknown. This thesis research aims to combine worldwide sampling of new and known prorhynchids with the collection of genome-wide DNA sequence data from many dozens of species to arrive for the first time at an unbiased picture of their global diversification.

The purpose of this dissertation improvement grant is to support the development of a novel method to cheaply sequence hundreds of genes from arbitrarily large numbers of organisms, which will contribute to an ongoing revolution in the way biologists analyze the evolutionary relationships of closely-related species, the leaves of the tree of life. Applying this method to prorhynchids, and showcasing these and other microscopic invertebrates to undergraduate students and community members (in collaboration with a local science education organization), will serve to further engage both scientific and public interest in such organisms, the largest and simultaneously least-understood components of global animal biodiversity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Flatworms are a group of microscopic invertebrates that live as predators and scavengers in aquatic and humid terrestrial habitats around the world, and as parasites in diverse vertebrate and invertebrate animals. While some species are of medical importance or are used as models for biological processes of interest to applied researchers (e.g. regeneration), most species have no direct societal significance, and consequently only a small fraction of the diversity of the group is known, and many mysteries surrounding the evolution of these simple animals remain. This project focused on understanding the evolution and diversity of one particular such flatworm group, Prorhynchida, using signals in molecular sequences encoded in their genomes. Using previously collected DNA samples of nearly 60 species found in freshwater and terrestrial habitats throughout the US and the world, and representing most of the known evolutionary diversity of the group, we prepared each species for whole genome shotgun sequencing using Illumina sequencing, the same technique used in most modern studies of human genomics. However, because the genomes of prorhynchids are too large to sequence each species fully, we developed a new molecular biological technique to reduce each genome sample to a small set of genes useful for evolutionary analysis. Briefly, we extracted RNA from two common species, representing the set of expressed genes in that sample, and used these extractions to generate synthetic RNA probes complimentary to these original genes. We also prepared sequencing samples directly from these and other RNAs, which we used directly as a sample of protein-coding genes. Using these transcriptomic data, we conducted an analysis of the interrelationships between all major flatworm groups, discovering unexpected evidence that Prorhynchida is closely related to the diverse marine group Polycladida. This study was recently published in a high-impact general readership biology journal: http://elifesciences.org/content/4/e05503.

Our enrichment protocol consisted of a hybridization of each species’ DNA sample to these RNA probes, and removed all regions that did not hybridize to these probes, as a means of selecting the most conserved regions in each genome. We then combined these enriched genome samples and sequenced the pool with a fraction of the sequencing effort that would be required to assemble the full genome of a single species, yielding roughly 4-5 million 125 base pair sequence reads per species. Assemblies of these enriched genome samples yield, on average, nearly 5000 contiguous stretches of DNA per species, totaling over 1.8 million base pairs, although the size of these assemblies varies by almost two orders of magnitude among the nearly 60 species on which we employed this method. This variation likely reflects in part evolutionary distance from the cDNA probe-seed species, and in part the innate quality/input quantity of DNA available from each species. Assembled sequences show a tight distribution of sizes around ~400 bp, likely reflecting the mean exon (coding sequence) length of prorhynchid genomes. Qualitatively, the vast majority of assembled sequences appear to contain a single fragment of conserved (albeit not necessarily well-annotated) protein-coding sequence, although this method also does show signs of enriching some repetitive DNA sequences as well.
